title: 105_s2355
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truancy Prevention and Juvenile Crime Reduction Act of 1998". Congress finds that truancy is a significant indicator of a young person's struggles, leading to school dropout, welfare dependency, unemployment, and criminal behavior. High rates of truancy are linked to high daytime burglary rates and vandalism, with up to 44 percent of violent juvenile crime occurring during school hours. Around 75 percent of children aged 13-16 who are arrested for crimes are truants, and some cities report up to 70 percent of unexcused student absences. This leads to significant social and economic costs for society. Truancy leads to high social and economic costs, with unexcused student absences reaching 4,000 per day in some cities. The consequences include a low educational attainment rate among inmates, high dropout rates, and a significant financial burden on the nation due to lost earnings and crime control costs. Effective truancy prevention programs can reduce the staggering costs of lost earnings and crime control. Lack of targeted funding hinders current law's ability to address truancy effectively. SEC. 3. GRANTS. In this section, "eligible partnership" refers to a partnership between local government units and educational agencies. "Local educational agency" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Qualified unit of local government" is a local government unit with specific criteria in place. A "qualified unit of local government" is a local government entity that meets specific criteria outlined in the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974. The term "unit of local government" refers to various types of political subdivisions within a state or Indian tribe. The government includes various political subdivisions of a State or Indian tribe. The Attorney General grants funds to partnerships to reduce truancy and juvenile crime, with a maximum grant of $100,000 per year. At least 25% of each grant must be allocated. In any fiscal year, the maximum grant for an eligible partnership is $100,000. At least 25% of the grant must be allocated to the local educational agency. Grants can be renewed for up to 2 additional fiscal years. Grant funds can be used to address truancy comprehensively. Grant amounts under this section can be used by eligible partnerships to address truancy through parental involvement, sanctions, parental accountability, and in-school prevention programs. Parental accountability measures for truancy prevention include fines, teacher-aid duty, community service, in-school programs, involvement of various community entities, technology use, and elimination of the 40-day count. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for programs that replicate model truancy intervention projects in Fulton County, Georgia, and Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for truancy intervention programs in various locations such as Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Roswell, New Mexico, Rohnert Park, California, New Haven, Connecticut, Atlantic County, New Jersey, and Oklahoma City. The Attorney General may prioritize funding for truancy intervention programs in various locations, including Atlantic County, New Jersey, Oklahoma City, Norfolk, Virginia, Marion, Ohio, Bakersfield, California, Farmington, New Mexico, and other model programs deemed appropriate. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 1999, 2000, and 2001 to carry out the program.
